article.title: A Faster Implementation of Online Run-Length Burrows-Wheeler Transform

multiple_choice_question.text: What data structure is represented by the tree labeled "T_all" in Figure 1?
choices: A binary search tree
A dynamic wavelet tree
A searchable partial sums with indels (SPSI) data structure
A suffix array

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the numbers in the leaves of the tree labeled "T_a" represent?
choices: The starting positions of all \'a\' runs in X
The total number of \'a\'s in X
The exponents of the runs of \'a\'s in X
The ranks of all \'a\'s in X

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the two rows within each internal node of the trees?
choices: They store the characters and their frequencies in the corresponding subtrees.
They represent the minimum and maximum exponents in the corresponding subtrees.
The first row stores the sum of #leaves, and the second row stores the sum of weights under the subtrees.
They are used for navigating the tree efficiently during search operations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What aspect of the data structure shown in Figure 1 leads to slow performance despite its theoretical time complexity?
choices: The use of SPSI data structures for storing exponents.
Storing two copies of each exponent in T_all and T_c.
The reliance on the \'H\' component to bridge T_all and T_c.
The use of gamma encoding for storing weights in bottom nodes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the T_all trees shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2?
choices: Figure 2 uses a different arity for internal nodes.
Figure 2 does not store the exponents in the leaves.
Figure 2 includes labels for the bottom nodes and pointers between corresponding leaves in T_all and T_c.
Figure 2 employs a different balancing scheme.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the "Change2" pointers in Figure 2?
choices: To connect each internal node of T_c to its parent node.
To link each leaf of T_c to the corresponding leaf in T_all.
To point from each internal node of T_c to its leftmost leaf.
To facilitate efficient updates after insertions or deletions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What optimization is indicated by the "Change5" label in Figure 2?
choices: Storing the character \'a\' in each bottom node of T_a.
Discarding the LA values and leaf-level weights in T_c.
Using bidirectional pointers for "Change1" instead of unidirectional pointers.
Utilizing the order-maintenance algorithm for maintaining labels in Change4.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary advantage of the data structure shown in Figure 2 compared to Figure 1?
choices: It reduces the overall space complexity.
It improves query time by avoiding reliance on the \'H\' component.
It simplifies the implementation of update operations.
It reduces the number of comparisons required during searches.
